Award.AwardTitle: CS Gateways 2015: Sustaining NSF-Supported Computer Science Education Curricula

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
CS Gateways 2015 is a two-day workshop for selected project leaders from NSF-supported computer science instructional material and professional development projects. The workshop will provide an opportunity for those leaders to think collectively about the scalability and long-term sustainability of their work, as well as support structures for long-term implementation and growth.

The broad goals of the conference are to
-- Inspire the project leaders to think beyond the development activities of their NSF-funded projects and to commit to taking steps that will lead to long-term growth and sustainability once NSF funding has ended;

-- Educate the participants about key issues that should be considered now in order to facilitate scalability and sustainability of their work; provide models of potential routes to scalability and sustainability; and

-- Strengthen the community of CS curriculum and professional developers; encourage collaboration and sharing of ideas and solution strategies.

The workshop represents a continuation of a series of NSF sponsored "Gateways" conferences where mathematics and science curriculum developers met annually to share experiences, discuss challenges, find and identify joint solutions, and build a community of educators and leaders focused on instructional material and professional development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CS Gateways 2015 was proposed as a two-day workshop for selected project leaders from NSF-supported, K-12 computer science instructional materials and professional development projects. The project evolved into two workshops, the first held November 15-15, 2015 in Chicago, IL, with a follow up workshop held January 31, 2016 in National Harbor, MD. The two workshops provided an opportunity for the leaders of computer science education projects to collectively think about how to prepare their work for scalability and long-term sustainability, and to consider the support structures needed for effective, long-term implementation and growth.

 The workshops continued the tradition of the NSF-supported Gateways conferences from the 1990s through the early 2000s, whereby mathematics and science curriculum developers met annually to share experiences, discuss key issues, seek joint solutions to commonly held problems, and develop a collaborative community of instructional materials development and professional development leaders.

 The November, two-day workshop included 25 participants from the computer science projects, representing 13 different projects. The agenda included presentations, panel discussions, and interactive sessions that addressed various topics related to the long-term sustainability of the program.  Speakers included representatives from publishing, school districts, NSF, and experts in scaling and sustaining other NSF-supported instructional materials.

 The January follow-up workshop involved 24 participants from 13 computer science projects. Agenda topics included more discussion of models for sustaining and scaling programs, issues related to the College Board’s Advanced Placement program, funding opportunities, and a variety of issues related to the broader computer science education community. The follow-up workshop included larger blocks of time for interactive discussions, with a goal of helping to strengthen the community of NSF-supported computer science educators.

Results from evaluation surveys from both workshops were overwhelmingly positive, with nearly all respondents noting that the workshops were beneficial and well organized, and expressing an interest in continuing the gatherings.

 


Last Modified: 06/23/2016
Modified by: Martin Gartzman
